titlestmt.title: PCT 02: The Character and Knowledge of the Cree
titlestmt.author: Louis Moosomin

bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: PCT 02: The character and knowledge of the Cree

p.seg: êkwah kotak , apisîs . Now another, a short one.

nayêstaw wâpiski-wiyâs maci-manitôwah wiya ê-kiskinôhamâkot wêyôtisiwin , êkosi niyanân mâskôc namoya nikiskêyimikonân maci-manitôwah . Since only the White Man was taught by the Evil Spirit how to acquire wealth, perhaps we others are not known to the Evil Spirit.
êkô ohci k-ôh-kitimâkisiyâhk . That is why we are poor.

pikw îtê êh-pîhtokêyit ayîsiyiniwah , kiyâm owêyôtisiwah , asamêw ; namwâc ahpôh wîhkâc tipahikêhêw . wherever it be, if a man, and be he a rich man, enters a dwelling, he gives him food; in no case does he make him pay for it.

kiyâm pêyakwâw kita-mîcisot êh-ayât nêhiyaw , êyiwêhk kaskihtâw wîcih-ayîsiyiniwah êh-asamât . Even if the Cree has enough for only a single meal, in some way he manages to give food to his fellow-man.

misiwê ôma askiy nêhiyaw kisêwâtisiwin êh-ayât , êwako piko , kisêwâtisiwin mâwacih êh-ayât , kahkiyaw wîc-âyîsiyiniwah kitimâkêyimêw nêhiyaw . Because, of all this earth, the Cree has most human kindness, because he has more human kindness than all others, the Cree deals kindly with all his fellow-men.
êwak ôhcih pikw îsih kâ-tôtâkot môniyâw-iyiniwa . That is why the Canadian has been able to do whatever he pleased to him.
êkosi êsi-kiskêyihtamân . that is as I know it from experience.
namoya nikîh-wanihtânân nêhiyaw ôtah askihk kâ-kîh-isi-pakitiniht . We cannot lose the ways with which the Cree was set down here on earth.
êkwah kayâs êsah pêyak nâpêw êh-manitôwit , kîtahtawêh akâmaskîhk ohcih nôcihâw . We are told that in ancient times a certain man who had spirit power was persecuted from across the sea.
pôtih nipahâw . The outcome was that he was slain.

êkwah kîtahtawê akâmaskîhk k-âyâcik ayîsiyiniwak , mac-âyîsiyiniwak , pîwâpisk ohcih mânah ayîsiyiniwah êh-osihâcik , ôki wanipahtâkêw-iyiniwak , nîstanaw êhtasicik . At that time across the sea there were some men, evil men, who made men out of iron, did those persecutors, who were twenty in number.
êkwah kotak awa oskinîkiw kâ-kiskêyihtahk ê-wih-kakwê-nipahiht , wawêyîw ; Then another man, a youth, who knew that they were going to try to kill him made himself ready;
asiskîwinisôw ; wâpiskâyik asiskiy âpacihtâw . he painted himself with clay; he used white clay.
nipîhk êsah waskic pimohtêw , mistah êh-manitôwit . he walked over the surface of the water, so great was his spirit power.

êkwah êh-takohtêt êkotê ispimihk , wîkiyihk pakicîw ôhih kâ-wih-kakwê-nipahikot . Then, when he arrived up aloft, at the others' dwelling he alighted, at the dwelling of those who were going to try to kill him. LB: The words suggest flying; probably I missed a word that said this; compare the return journey, below.

wâpamêwak ;
kihiw , itêyimêwak . They saw him; they thought he was an eagle.

seg.gloss: “And did I not fear him whom we were going to try to kill?

p.seg: ahpôh êtokê êwakô ! itêw awa kâ-wih-kakwê-nipahât , pîwâpisk ê-macostêkahk ayîsiyiniwah êh-osihât mâna êsah awa mac-âyîsiyiniw . I should not be surprised if this were he!” said the one who was going to try to kill him, putting iron into the hot fire to make a man, as was that evil person's way.
êwak ôhci k-ô-kî-sâkwêyimoyân , ê-sîhkimiyak , itêw êsah ; “This was why I was unwilling, when you urged me,” he told the others;
êkwah êwako êtok âwah ! itêw . “No doubt this is he!” he told them.
kiyâm pîhtokêh ! kitimâkêyiminân ; pê-pîhtwâ ! itêw êsah . “Enter, please! Take pity pn us; come and smoke!” he said to him.

seg.gloss: “Ho, I do not wish to smoke.

p.seg: kiyâm kipê-miyitinâwâw t-si-nipahiyêk , itwêw êsah . If so please you, I have come to let you kill me, as you desire,” he told them.
hâ , namoya ka-kîh-nipahikawin ! itâw ; “Oh, it will be impossible to kill you!” he answered him;

êh-ati-itiht ,
kiyâm kitimâkêyiminân ! itik ôhi mac-âyîsiyiniwah ; as he continued to be spoken to in this way, “Please have mercy on us!” he was asked by those evil persons;

namoya ! itêw ;
kipê-miyitinâwâw t-si-nipahiyêk , itêw . No!” he told them; “I have come to let you kill me,” he told them.
namoya ka-kîh-nipahitinân , itik . “We could not kill you,” they told him.

seg.gloss: “Well then, I shall wait until dark.
If you do not intend to kill me, I shall go home as I am.

p.seg: mâka kik-âswêyiminâwâw , itwêw . But I shall be on the lookout for you,” he said.
êh-tipiskâyik êkwah , êh-kîwêt , mosci-pimihâw êkwah . When darkness came and he went home, he merely flew.

êh-wâpahk ntomêw êsah kahkiyaw kâ-mitêwiyit ayîsiyiniwah , kit-ôsîhtâyit mitêwikamik . On the next day he summoned all the people who took part in the Medicine Ceremony, to have them build a Medicine Lodge. LB: Unless I greatly misjudge, the informant here gives a more favorable account of the Mitewin than could be got from other Sweet-Grass Cree. He spent some years at an institution for the blind at Winnipeg, where he may have consorted with Ojibwa.
êkwah kiyâm pêyak êh-ayât awiyak maskihkiy , kit-êtohtatâw , êkosi itêw ayîsiyiniwah ; “And please let anyone who has any medicine bring it there,” he told the people;

seg.gloss: “Work with zeal; help me in what I am doing;

p.seg: osâm mistahi kinipahikonawak , itwêw ; too many of us are being killed,” he told them;

kisihtâyêkoh ômah k-ôsîhtâyêk mitêwikamik , minah kahkiyaw kîsihtâyêkoh , tahtoh ayîsiyiniwak ka-wih-itohtêcik kîsi-pîhtokêtwâwe , êkospih ka-pê-ntominâwâw , itwêw awa oskinîkiw ; “When you have finished the Medicine Lodge which you are building, and have completed everything, and when as many persons as mean to go there, have entered the lodge, then you are to come and call me,” said that youth;
êkwah pîhtokêyâni , nistikwânihk ka-pakamahonâwâw , itwêw aw ôskinîkiw ; “And when I enter the lodge, you are to strike me on my head,” said the youth;
nika-pimitâcimon , pîhtokêyânih , itwêw ; “I shall be crawling along the ground, when I enter the lodge,” he said;
êkwah mîna nîstanaw atimwak ka-mowâwâwak , itwêw ; “Also, twenty dogs you will eat,” he said;
êkwah kahkiyaw kika-nîmihitonâwâw , itwêw aw ôskinîkiw ; “And all of you will dance,” said the youth;

seg.gloss: “And when you have slain me, you will cut me open.
Off to one side you will place it.
Opposite the doorway you will lay blue mats.
And red matting you will lay toward the doorway.

p.seg: tâpiskôc nipêwinis kk-êsihtânâwâw , itwêw êsah ; You will make something like a small bed,”

seg.q: êkotê niyaw iskwâhtêmihk itêy isih , sâkâstênohk êkotêh isi nk-aspiskwêsimon .
seg.gloss: “And there my body, towards the doorway, facing the direction whence comes the light of day, I shall lie with my head on it.

p.seg: êkwah kapê-tipisk kika-nîmihitonâwâw , itwêw êsah ; And all night you are to dance,” he told them;

seg.gloss: And two knives will hang by my head as I lie.

p.seg: kîspin kêkway mihkoh wâpahtamêko , êkosi nika-sâkohâwak akâmaskihk k-âyâcik ayîsiyiniwak , itwêw êsah . If you see any blood, then I shall be defeating those persons who are across the sea,” he told them.
tâpwê ntaw-osîhtâniwiw mitêwikamik . Accordingly they went and built a Medicine Lodge.

itwêw ,
kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwak omaskihkîmiwâwa , mîna mitonih kahkiyaw kîh-mêsci-pîhtokêyêkôh , êkospihk kika-pê-pêkominâwâw . He said, “When the medicines of all the people are there, and when all of you, completely and to the last one, have entered the lodge, then you will come and wake me by speech.
pita niwîh-nipân , itwêw êsah . Meanwhile I wish to sleep,” he said.
tâpwê sôhkih atoskêwak ayîsiyiniwak , mitêwikamik êh-osîhtâcik . Accordingly the people worked diligently, building a Medicine Lodge.
êkwah t-êtohtêt pê-ntomâw , ê-kih-kîsihtâwiht . Then he was summoned to go there, when it had been completed for him.
kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwah êh-kîsi-pîhtokêyit , itohtêw . When all the people had gone in, he went there.
hâw , niwâhkomâkanitik , kiyâm nipakitêyimâw nikosis , itwêyiwah ôhtâwiya ; “Now then, O my kinsmen, if so please you, I give up my son,” spoke his father;
mayaw pîhtokêcih nipahâhkêk , itwêyiwa . “As soon as he enters, kill him,” he said.

êkosi wiya ,
nipahihkêk ! itwêyiwa . It was his own father who said, “Kill him!”

ôma k-êsi-sîhkimikoyêk kakwê-tôtamok , itwêyiwa ôhtâwiya , mâka wiya kisêyiniw pêkitêyimât ôh ôkosisah . “Try to do this in the way that he has bidden you,” said his father, the old man himself thus offering up his son.
mayaw êh-pîhtokê-pimitâcimowit , pakamahomâwa ostikwâniyihk . As soon as the latter crawled into the lodge, he was struck on the head.
kakwêyahôwak oskinîkiwak omatôwahk wâskikaniyihk ê-yâyikiswâcik . The young men went faithfully to work, slashing him open here at his chest.
êkwah tâpwê pimisimêwak oma kâ-kîh-isi-sîhkimikocik . Then they laid him down in the way he had bidden them.
kahkiyaw êkosi tôtamwak . They did it all in that way.
êkâ mâh nântaw mêcimwâcih nipahâyêkoh nikosis ! itwêw awa kisêyiniw kêsêwâtisit . Remember that you have not by any means really slain my son!” said the old man, so generous was he.
tâpwêh nîmihitôwak kapê-tipisk . Accordingly they danced all night.
êh-pêh-wâpaniyik , kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahkik mihkoh môkomânihkânihk êh-pahpahkikawiyik . As dawn approached, there at one time they saw blood dripping from the blades of the knives.
êkwah tâpwê cihkêyihtamwak ê-nîmihitocik , nayêstaw atimwah êh-môwâcik . Then truly did they put their heart into the dance, and only dogs they ate.
pîsim êh-pê-sâkêwêt , êkoyikohk natawâpênâwâw awa oskinîkiw . When the sun rose above the horizon, they went to view that youth.
êkwah êkotah wâpahcikâtêw êh-âpisisihk . There it was seen by all that he returned to life.
kahkiyaw êsah kî-sâkôcihêw anihih nîstanaw tah ayîsiyiniwah . He had overcome all of those twenty persons.

kahkiyaw êsah oki-nâspici-nipâhtâwâw . It appears that they had all gone to sleep beyond hope of revival. Perhaps read {okî-nâspitsi-nipahâhtâwâw}: “they had killed him beyond the possibility of revival”.
êkotah ohci namoya êkoyikohk miywâsin mitêwikamik . but since then the Medicine Lodge has not been so good a thing as all that.

kahkiyaw kêkway mac-âyisak ahpôh ayîsiyiniwak kî-nâ-nipahitôwak , maci-maskihkiyah êh-âpacihtâcik , êh-pistispôwihtocik . All kinds of evil beings or person have killed one another, by using bad medicines to poison one another. CHECK pistispowihtocik
pikw îsi isi-kaskihtâwak êsi-nisiwanâcihitocik kayâs ayîsiyiniwak . The old-time people were able to do all manner of things in the way of destroying one another.
êwako wiyawâw ocipwêwak nîkân kâ-kîh-miyikôwisicik mitêwiwin ; It was the Ojibwa who first were given this Medicine Ceremony by the Higher Powers;
kêhciwâk kîh-itohtêwak mitêwi-manitôwah . they went into the actual presence of the Spirit of the Mitewin.

êkotah ohcih kahkiyaw kêkway nipîhk k-ôtaskiyit , êyakonik mâmostawêwak kâ-mitêwicik ; Since then, those who participate in the Medicine Rite, worship all those beings that have their home in the waters;
môhkiciwanipêkohk mînah k-ôtaskiyit kahkiyaw mawimostawêwak ; they worship also that being who has his home in springs;
mîna tahtoh kêkway kâ-sâkikihk ôtah askîhk , êwakonih kîh-kiskinôhamâkôwisiwak kit-si-mawimostahkik . and they were told by the spirits to worship as many things as grow forth out of this earth.

anohc kêyâpic mihcêt kêkway êh-pwâtawihtâcik maskihkîwiyiniwak , kaskihtâwak nêhiyawak omaskihkîmiwâwaw ohci ; To this day, many things which the physicians fail of doing, the Cree can do them through their medicines;
cikêmâ kîh-miyikôwisiw nêhiyaw maskihkiy ; what wonder, since the Cree was given medicine by the Higher Powers?

iyikohk êspîhcâk askiy , kahkiyaw kêkway kâ-wâpahtamihk , niyîpihkih kâw-ohpikihk , êspîhcâk askiy , misiwê kih-têpastawân nêhiyaw omaskihkîm . Over all the extent of the earth, everything that is seen growing forth in the summer time, as far as the earth extends, everywhere the medicine of the Cree was placed within his reach.

misiw îtê itâpiyêkoh ka-wâpahtênâwâw nêhiyaw êh-kîh-miyiht wîstah kit-ôhcih-pimâtisit . Wherever you may look, you will see that which the Cree, for his part, was given, that he might derive from it his continuance of life.
mîna âpihtaw êh-mâyâtaniyik maskihkiy kîh-miyâw . Also, as half of the gift, he was given bad medicine.

kahkiyaw kêkway kî-wîhtamâkôwisiwak kit-si-nanâtawihiwâkêcik , ahpôh nipîhk kahkiyaw kêkway k-ôhpikiniyik , kitâ-pâsahkik kahkiyaw kêkway maskihkiy . they were shown by the spirits every way of doctoring people, all the things, even, which grow in the water, that they might dry all kinds of medicinal herbs.
ohcitaw nitâyimôtên kayâs nêhiyawak kâh-isi-pimâtisicik . I tell this because I wish to discourse upon how the Cree lived of old.

nimiywêyihtên mantôw wiyah êh-itêyihtahk , awa nâpêw kâh-pêh-natawêyihtahk nêhiyaw tânisi kâ-k-îsi-pimâtisit . I am glad that the Lord had it in mind that this man should come here and desire to know how the Cree used to live.

mitonê mâka kahkiyaw miyo-kanâpamikôwisit ayîsiyiniw , êkwah kayâs nik-ayimôtên . How well the people of old were taken care of, in everything, by the Powers, of that I shall now speak. CHECK kanapamikowisit - either PCT or lexfile has typo
nama kêkway wiyasôwêwin ohc-ayâw nêhiyaw ; Originally the Cree had no kind of law;
wiyawâw piko ayîsiyiniwak omitonêyihcikaniwâw kîh-âpacihtawak . people simply used their own considerate judgment.
ayisk nêhiyaw nama kêkway ohci mâyi-tôtam ; For the Cree did not, by his original nature, do wrong;
namoya ohcih mâyi-tôtawêw nêhiyaw ksê-manitôwa . it is not in the nature of the Cree to do wrong to God.
êkwah nêhiyaw tipiyaw wiya manitôwa kîh-kakêskimik ; The Cree was instructed by God himself in person;
êyak ohci yôspisiwin k-ôh-ayât nêhiyaw . that is why the Cree has gentleness.
ayisk kisêwâtisiw , manitôw kâ-kîh-pêh-kakêskimât ayîsiyiniwah . For he has kindness of heart, since God came and instructed the people.
êkwah mîna piko iskwêwa kîh-nâ-naskowasimik ; êkosi kîh-wiyasôwatêw . At that time only the woman made rejoinders to Him; therefore He pronounced the law for her. LB: For {kîh-nâ-naskwêwasimik}.

seg.q: nama wîhkâc mistahi kita-yâhkastêw kitatoskêwin ; osâm kinâ-naskowasimin .
seg.gloss: “Never shall your work show great advance; for you have retorted to me.

p.seg: kiyâm kapê-kîsik atoskêyanih , pêyakwan iyikohk kit-êspîhcipayiw kitatoskêwin , kîh-itêw êsa manitôw . Let it be that when you work all day, your work will be as far advanced as it was before,” God said to her.
êwakoni pikoh ôhi pêh-mâyasôwâtêw . For her alone He decreed ill.
nâpêwa kîh-kiyâmapiyiwa , oskac nêhiyaw êw-osihiht . The man stayed still when the Cree was first made.
êkosi êsa kîh-ispayiw , itwêwak kayâs kisêyiniwak , oskac êw-osihât manitôw nêhiyawah . Thus it must have gone, said the old men of yore, when God first made the Cree.
êkosi êsa kây-ispayik . So that is the way it must have happened.
êkotah kî-wîhtamôwêw kahkiyaw kêkway maskihkiyah , mîna mawimoscikêwin kit-âyâyit . There He told him every kind of medicine, and the religion he was to have.
êkoyikohk wiya mantôw ohcih nka-pôni-âyimohtên . And at this point I shall cease to discourse of things concerning the Lord.
êkwah niwîh-âtayôhkân . Now I shall tell a sacred story.
êyôkô pêyak âcimowin . And so this is one discourse.
nînân mîna nitayânân manitôw okiskinôhamâkêwin . We, too, have a teaching of God.
ayisk namoya niyanân n-ôh-nipahânân manitôw okosisa ; You see, not we have ever slain God's Son;
êywak ôhci namoya nnisitawêyimikonân maci-manitôw . that is why the Evil One does not know us.
êwak ôhci êkâ kêkway kaskihtâwin k-ôh-ayâyâhk . And that is why we have no kind of worldly power.
